captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Christ, it really isn&#39;t the 90&#39;s anymore, is it. 
You make a game about a scantily clad girl with

a big bum these days, it&#39;s like releasing 
an affectionate dog into a sterile allergen

testing laboratory. Half the internet yells about 
objectified women and the other half yells at the

first half that they&#39;ve no right to oppress 
the artistic statement intended by letting

the protagonist&#39;s camel toe flap in the breeze, 
and it&#39;s like two monkeys having a shit fight

on a merry-go-round. No one gets anywhere and no 
one gets to ride the ponies. Well you know what,

for all the sexiness of the main character of 
Stellar Blade and for all the bigness of her bum,

it&#39;s kinda justified. Because it&#39;s a post-humanist 
sci-fi setting where everyone&#39;s in custom robot

bodies, and I&#39;d argue that if you could put on 
whatever body you wanted every morning like a

fresh pair of underpants, then yeah, most of 
us probably would be hot girls with big bums.

I know I would. Make it a lot easier to get into 
nightclubs. And I could use my cleavage to store

small objects and biros. Not sure I&#39;d want to 
wear what look like the most agonizingly painful

high heels in the universe that are one set of 
horns away from being Pan&#39;s Labyrinth cosplay,

but all the same, rest assured I won&#39;t judge 
you for your big bum hot girls, Stellar Blade.

&quot;Thanks, Yahtz!&quot; Now what&#39;s the rest of your game 
like? &quot;Really fucking boring, as it happens!&quot;

Well, I&#39;ll judge you for THAT. It doesn&#39;t help 
that it&#39;s THAT plot again. Standard anime sci

fi template plot no. 3. Earth is devastated by 
monsters of mysterious origin, last vestige of

humanity attempts to fight back with astonishingly 
advanced technology that for unclear reasons is

exclusively wielded by questionably of age people 
in disquietingly sexy outfits. Then it&#39;ll turn out

the monsters were humans or created by humans or 
manifestations of the human fondness for pancakes

or something and everyone gets angsty about it. 
Without wishing to spoil, there&#39;s a choice of two

final boss fights in Stellar Blade thanks to an 
endingtron 3000 situation - one of them is a tween

piloting a giant robot, the other is a shirtless 
dude with three angel wings. It&#39;s like they threw

a dart at the big board of anime cliches and 
the point of the dart was three feet wide. It

also doesn&#39;t help that the main character, 
Eve, has the personality of a remedially

educated barnacle. Big bum and all. See, it&#39;s 
not like the Bayonetta thing where the flamboyant

personality of the protagonist is expressed 
through the medium of large bottom gyrations.

Eve goes about things like a fucking Realdoll 
programmed with the personality of another, more

downmarket Realdoll. Oh and incidentally yeah, her 
name&#39;s EVE. She&#39;s the last survivor of her people

stuck on ravaged post-apocalyptic Earth and she&#39;s 
called Eve, and if you think Stellar Blade isn&#39;t

going to bring in themes of rebirthing humanity 
possibly with the aid of a male character named

Adam then you&#39;re clearly giving Stellar Blade way 
too much fucking credit. Stellar Blade plays like

if Nier Automata received a traumatic brain injury 
that dropped its IQ points by an entire digit,

killed every original thought in its head and made 
it pathologically fixated on big bums. More so,

I mean. And if all the voice acting in 
the English dub at least was performed by

whatever DoorDash driver was bringing lunch 
to the office that day. It&#39;s a third person

hack and slash that I&#39;d call a little bit 
spectacle fighter-y - sure is a spectacle

if you pick an outfit with a miniskirt, hurr 
hurr gender politics - taking place half the

time in open-ended ruined landscapes 
with multiple sidequests and half the

time in linearly laid out ruined landscapes 
that hit copy paste a few too many times.

The environments also have this occasional 
fondness for really unnecessarily huge rooms.

That never fail to make me go &quot;Boy, I wonder 
when we&#39;re going to fight a boss here,

and not just run in a straight line across 
empty floor for forty-five seconds.&quot; But until

we figure out a way to harness clean energy 
from anime game jiggle physics the one thing

that might save Stellar Blade is the combat. 
And only because it&#39;s basically functional and

gives you something to do with your hands. 
Besides, you know, the obvious. It&#39;s the

usual arrangement for third person melee combat - 
light attack, heavy attack, parry, dodge, block,

that&#39;s how we sing the melee combat rock. With 
timed perfect parries and perfect dodges as well,

with a sort of Sekiro-like heavy emphasis on the 
former because following the trend for soulslikes

these days most of the bosses&#39; preferred strategy 
is to spazz out like an arachnophobic drummer

practicing in a poorly maintained garden shed. 
And I found I could perfect parry their comboes

fairly consistently just by in return spazzing 
out on the block button. Like an arachnophobic.

Me. Noticing a spider. On the block button. So 
that&#39;s the core of it, we add probably a few too

many additional super attacks and Rage of the Gods 
modes along the course of events, including a gun.

Which is mostly so useless during the usual 
melee business they have to have entire sections

of the game where it&#39;s the only thing you&#39;re 
allowed to use possibly to justify it on their

tax return. All in all I struggle to think of 
any area in which Stellar Blade isn&#39;t boring,

baseline and/or hackneyed. Even the final boss 
is a boring twat. Especially before the three

angel wings pop out. And afterwards only less 
so because you find yourself wondering how

he&#39;d ever fit inside a public convenience. 
The environments range from ruins to desert

ruins to more desert ruins to ruined sewers 
to a space elevator which I suppose is more

interesting but then it gets ruined. Half 
the side missions are just &quot;find corpse,

go back to hub town and report corpse to corpse&#39;s 
friend / wife / cousin / occupational therapist.&quot;

I don&#39;t think there was a single plot twist 
I didn&#39;t predict. Like at the very start your

mentor dramatically sacrifices themselves so 
you can escape but you never see a body so I

was like &quot;okay, see you later when you&#39;re a 
boss fight, I guess.&quot; Oh! Hang on! I thought

of something. I was impressed by the relative 
lack of invisible walls in Stellar Blade.

Most of the time in this sort of thing if you 
see a pile of collapsed debris - and you&#39;ll see

a fucking lot of that in Stellar Blade - that 
would be environment design shorthand for &quot;no

go this way,&quot; but I was surprised by how often 
I was permitted to just climb over such things,

and often there&#39;d be a secret behind it, although 
usually it&#39;d just contain crafting materials for

making purely cosmetic outfi- oh wait a second. 
I think I figured out Stellar Blade&#39;s unique

selling point. Everything else, the plot, 
the combat, the world, is too generic to be

anything but the foundation, the frame around 
what&#39;s really important which it turns out

is dress-up dollies. The unlockable outfits are 
where all the creative effort seems to have gone,

none of them would be out of place on stage at a 
future avant-garde fashion show for rich people

with some kind of bizarre grudge against their 
own buttholes. And I did think it was weird how

the only reward for a major sidequest early on 
was unlocking the ability to change my hairdo.

But why criticize, y&#39;know? More bridges should 
be built between the people who want to dress

up Barbies and the people who want to jerk 
off to big bums. Maybe Stellar Blade could

bring all those people together. Hopefully 
in a room with adequate air conditioning.
